captions.text:
Dreams are an amazing phenomenon -- and considering
you spend roughly 6 years of your life dreaming,

it's quite curious that we often brush them
aside to be quickly forgotten. Night after

night our brains go to work and bring us some
of the most incredible, bizarre and often

seemingly random imagery and storylines. But...what
are dreams? And like the many science fiction

stories or movies, could we ever record and
figure out what we're seeing while we're dreaming?

You may have heard of people referring to
'brain waves' before, but have you ever stopped

to think: are these actual waves, and do they...
carry information? Are brain waves similar

to, say, radio waves? The answer is, yes;
both brain and radio waves are forms of electromagnetic

radiation -- waves that travel at the speed
of light. Every time you think, thousands

of neurons fire at the same frequency and
generate a wave. These waves oscillate at

around 10 to 100 cycles per second. Radio
waves, on the other hand oscillate at around

50...million to 1 billion times per second.
Scientists have long used this phenomenon

to measure brain activity and interface the
brain to electronic devices. It allows us

to see which parts of the brain are active
for different activities, and similarly which

parts of the brain are active during dreaming.
Strange as it may seem, we still barely understand

why we sleep let alone why we dream. Michael
from Vsauce does a fantastic job explaining

the main theories for why we dream. But there
are so many theories because we can't really

measure or know what people are dreaming about,
without waking them up and asking them. Of

course, this is subject to forgetting or other
errors. Unfortunately, there is no device

that exists to allow us to peer into the mind
of a dreamer...or is there?

Crazy as it sounds, scientists have created
a technique to do just that. This mind-reading

technology began with a functional MRI Scanner,
inside which subjects were shown simple pictures

made up of black and white pixels. The software
then finds patterns in the brain activity

that corresponds to the specific images. For
example, if the letter "T" was shown, the

software would record exactly how the brain
reacted. After sufficient data, the subjects

were then shown completely different images,
and the software would predict and recreate

what it thought the subjects were seeing.
After being shown the word "Neuron" these

were the images the software generated.
But it doesn't stop there -- further studies

began to use more complex visuals during the
subjects sleep. In this case, they first had

the subjects fall asleep while in an fMRI,
and would wake them up in the middle of dreaming,

quickly asking them what they were dreaming
about. They then used thousands of images

from the internet to get a best approximation
of what the subject was seeing based on brain

scans. After doing this nearly 200 times with
each person, and plugging the information

into a learning algorithm, software was used
to predict and generate their future dreams.

Though by no means perfect, it was clear that
the machines predictions were better than

chance, matching up with the dreamers description.
Perhaps even more shocking is a study that

actually used video footage; after showing
subjects 2 hours of movie footage and analyzing

their brain activity, they then used a library
of 18 million, 1 second YouTube clips to match

the brain activity. Here are the results:
On the left are new, unrelated clips that

the subjects were later shown, and on the
right is what the software guessed they were

seeing, using a mashed up combination of the
YouTube clips as an approximation. All of

this based on their brain waves.
As these software programs become more and

more complex, we come that much closer to
accurately visualizing and recording our thoughts

and dreams. At which point, perhaps, we'll
have a few more clues into why we dream, in

the first place.
And if you'd like to find out about other

amazing and unanswered scientific phenomenon,
head over to All Time 10's channel, where

10 fantastic science YouTubers have come together
in an attempt to answer some burning questions.

It's a super-collaboration of SCIENCE!
And if you're new to AsapSCIENCE, be sure

to subscribe for more weekly science videos!
We've made a playlist of some of our favourite

and most popular videos for your viewing pleasure.
Enjoy!

I once had a freaky dream that I still remember, after like 10 years.

It started with me casually waking up and going outside. But then, the sky 
got dark and some objects turned monochrome. My teacher was waiting for me, 
and forced me to do some strange puzzles, that I don't remember as much. 
She said that the world would end if I failed. I did fail though. In the 
end, a Cthulu-like creature appeared, and shot me in the chest a couple of 
times. The last thing I saw before waking up was a shot of the Earth 
exploding.

I literally jumped out of my bed. Oddly enough, I still felt a strong pain 
in my chest area.﻿

comments.text:
Does this mean by recording our brain waves every night we can find what 
personality we have by using recurring images and thoughts and comparing 
them to templates of similar personalities? If so, using this method can we 
transfer our personality's data into AI that can respond to messages by 
pulling up similar responses we had in our dreams? For example, one week a 
test is done in which pictures, information, and words are shown and our 
responses are recorded and compared with other responses to similar 
information shown. The average response is then sent to the AI so that when 
similar information is shown, a similar message is responded? Simple tasks, 
like saying "Hi" can be done completely by the AI, while more complex tasks 
like responses to asking the AI-Personality Integrated machine questions 
like "Do you like to watch Nicki Minaj's Anaconda video?" can be elicited 
by the recorded average response the real person make. This method could be 
a great grief relief for people who have recently lost a loved one and miss 
them terribly.﻿

comments.author: irelandcool1

comments.text:
I always wonder about the people in my dreams. Are they parts of me? Or 
does my brain try to generate people who are nothing like me because I 
subconsciously desire companionship? And then, assuming the latter is true, 
does my brain fail at doing so? They could be the smallest parts of me that 
reject the most key parts of myself and so, are with, and without (if I may 
quote F. Scott Fitzgerald), they are a manifestation of my most distant 
parts, created as such to appear as someone who is not me. So am I able to 
press these characters for information so that I may better understand 
myself, and for that matter, if I am aware of it, will it affect the 
outcome? Could I simply hear what I most want to? That I am kind and brave, 
making myself believe so, because, after all, I heard if from a 
manifestation of my own self? Or will that manifestation of my 
subconscious, THAT me, not realize who I am, that I am me? If so, will I 
receive the answer that a stranger to that part of me would receive? And 
could I take that answer as a sign that my smaller parts are so different 
from my main self, or so distant from my main self that I could not even 
recognize myself? Am I only subject to myself in my dreams, can my brain 
find no true inspiration?

It would be amazing to dream and for the self to completely reconfigure 
itself and to be someone not YOU, you, the first person character 
experiencing the story, are not yourself, merely a projection of your 
subconscious or maybe even a representation of how you believe others act, 
or how someone in particular acts if you become them in your dreams. Or is 
it that human nature has basic guidelines that are preordained and thus you 
ARE in fact capable of unbiasedly fabricating a person whom with you do not 
share a piece of your mind with.

Ugh...questions questions and NO answers. Science shouldn't boast if it has 
only come THIS far.﻿

comments.text:
My biggest concern with the whole "Record brain activity during input, then 
use the data to figure out what they're thinking about" technique is this: 
If you recorded one person's data, then used it with another person, I'm 
fairly certain the results would be entirely different. So you'd need to 
record a large sample from each individual﻿

comments.text: Can lighting go through glass﻿
comments.author: kfrayn2003

comments.text:
+kfrayn2003 Lightning is not light. It is electricity. Glass is an 
insulator and cannot conduct electricity. Therefor it would not work and it 
also would not be able to even travel through a conductor.


In short: nope.

comments.author: GermanEnderHD

comments.text:
I think dreaming is an evolutionary trait, especially nightmares. It's been 
said that we have dreams based on things that have happened recently, so 
if, for example, a caveman was in a dangerous place, and had seen 
dangerous/scary things, he/she would have a nightmare to keep their brains 
in a constant state of emergency, so that they can react faster if danger 
comes to them. On the other hand, pleasant dreams might be to help our 
minds stay stable, and reinforce a feeling of safety.﻿
